item.title: Strikes on Syria Tied to Deaths of 52 Civilians
item.description: The toll from attacks by the American-led coalition on Friday included at least nine children, a rights group reported on Saturday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: More Rescues From Boko Haram Reported
item.description: Nigeria’s military rescued 234 more girls and women from a Boko Haram forest stronghold in the country’s northeast, according to a Twitter message from the Nigerian Defense Headquarters.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Burundi: 3 Die in Grenade Attacks
item.description: Three people have died in grenade attacks in Bujumbura, the capital, a spokesman for the public security ministry said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: 1,400 Migrants Rescued at Sea
item.description: Ships from Italy and France rescued more than 1,400 migrants on Saturday after smugglers’ boats ran into trouble in the Mediterranean Sea near Libya.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: France: Migrants Rescued at Sea
item.description: A French patrol ship rescued 217 migrants from three small boats that had run into trouble off the coast of Libya on Saturday, the maritime police said in a statement.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Maldives: Protest Leaders Arrested
item.description: The authorities have arrested three opposition leaders and nearly 200 other people after clashes erupted between the police and protesters.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Canada Promises More Aid
item.description: Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada made a surprise visit to Iraq on Saturday and pledged continued support for the country’s battle against the Islamic State group.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Suspects’ Videos Found
item.description: Violent extremist videos were found on a computer belonging to a couple suspected of preparing an attack on a cycling race, a police official said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Ruth Rendell, Novelist Who Thrilled and Educated, Dies at 85
item.description: Ms. Rendell, a Labour Party member of the House of Lords, was a prolific writer of intricately plotted mystery novels that combined psychological insight, social conscience and teeth-chattering terror.
item.dc:creator: DAVID STOUT
item.media:credit: Michael Falco for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ruth Rendell was a hugely popular British writer credited with pushing the mystery genre into new themes and ways of storytelling.

item.title: Nuns Intercede for Victims of Sex Trafficking in Italy
item.description: A group of nuns have opened their doors to African migrants who have found themselves caught up in the sex trade after arriving in Italy vulnerable and penniless.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sister Rita Giaretta, right, at the safe house in Caserta that has provided refuge to 370 women.

item.title: American Released by Cuba Plays Role as U.S. Relations With Havana Thaw
item.description: Alan Gross, an American who was imprisoned in Cuba for five years, is helping a new political action committee raise money to support freer trade and travel to the island.
item.dc:creator: RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: Alan Gross, with his wife, Judy, in Washington last year after he was freed from Cuba.

item.title: Kate, Duchess of Cambridge, Gives Birth to Baby Girl
item.description: The impending birth was cause for much excitement in Britain, not least among bookmakers.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Kate, Duchess of Cambridge, and Prince William, Duke of Cambridge, with their newborn daughter at St. Mary's Hospital in London on Saturday.

item.title: Hints of Normalcy in Katmandu, but Rebuilding Lies Ahead
item.description: A week after a severe earthquake struck Nepal, a growing number of its capital’s millions of residents were packing up their tents, checking out of hospitals and preparing for the workweek.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Villagers unloaded relief aid from an Indian Army helicopter at Ranehak, Nepal.

item.title: With Campaign Spending Limited, British Politicians Vie to Be ‘Liked’ and ‘Retweeted‘
item.description: Britain’s political parties have become even more reliant than their American counterparts on social media as a way to mobilize supporters for next week’s election.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron taking a “selfie” with Conservative Party activists last month.

item.title: Maimed Defending Afghanistan, Then Neglected
item.description: The number of Afghan soldiers and policemen who have permanent disabilities has soared, overwhelming resources available from the government and charitable organizations.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: White House Looks to Ease Arab Fears Over Iran Nuclear Pact
item.description: One option would put in writing, but not send to Congress, language agreeing to the defense of Arab allies if they came under attack from outside forces.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: The United States navy aircraft carrier U.S.S. George H.W. Bush in the Persian Gulf last year. Bahrain is the home of the Navy’s Fifth Fleet.

item.title: In Algeria, Entrepreneurs Hope Falling Oil Prices Will Spur Innovation
item.description: The organizers of a conference on business innovation preach diversification of the economy and optimism in the face of government warnings.
item.dc:creator: AIDA ALAMI
item.media:description: A commercial harbor in Algiers. The Algerian economy relies heavily on energy-related exports.

item.title: Afghanistan Begins Trial in Killing of Woman
item.description: Prosecutors said that the Islamic law student was beaten to death in an attack that was set off by a false accusation that she had burned a copy of the Quran.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: South Korean N.Y.U. Student Is Reported Arrested in North Korea
item.description: North Korea said that Joo Won-moon had been detained after crossing into the country from the Chinese town Dandong.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Kate, Duchess of Cambridge, Gives Birth to Baby Girl
item.description: The impending birth was cause for much excitement in Britain, not least among bookmakers.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: People celebrated outside St. Mary's Hospital in London on Saturday after the announcement of the birth of a daughter for Kate, the Duchess of Cambridge, and Prince William.
